  2. Homocysteine Methyl Transferase requires B12 activity to convert homocysteine to methionine.
  3. Methyl Folate Trap and Folate Deficiency - The production of methyl THFA is an irreversible step. Therefore, the only way for regeneration of free THFA is step No. 1 in Figure. When B12 is deficient, this reaction cannot take place. This is called the methyl folate trap. This leads to the associated folic acid scarcity in B12 deficiency.

 

 

Vitamin B12-dependent Enzymes:

 

1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase (Methylmalonyl CoA mutase): This enzyme converts methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA, a critical step in the catabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids. The enzyme requires adenosylcobalamin (Ado-B12) as a cofactor.

 

4. Methionine Synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine using methylcobalamin (Me-B12) as a cofactor. This reaction is crucial for the regeneration of methionine and the production of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), an essential methyl group donor in numerous methylation reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Homocysteine Synthase: There is no enzyme by this specific name, but homocysteine is converted to methionine by methionine synthase, which is vitamin B12-dependent.

 

3. Folate Reductase: This enzyme reduces dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), an essential step in folate metabolism. However, it does not require vitamin B12 as a cofactor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

 

The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

 

 

 

Metaplasia of normal columnar (left) to squamous epithelium (right) in a bronchus

 

  • Another example of metaplasia: BARRETTs esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal development or growth of cells, tissues, or organs. It is characterized by changes in cell size, shape, and organization. Dysplasia can be a precursor to cancer but does not describe the replacement of one cell type by another.

 

Option B. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy is the increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the tissue or organ. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Option C. Atrophy: Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of cells, tissues, or organs, often due to decreased use, insufficient nutrition, or aging. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman from a rural area presents to the gynecology outpatient department with complaints of abnormal uterine bleeding and cramping pelvic pain for the past six months. She has no significant past medical history and has never been pregnant. On pelvic examination, the uterus appears normal in size, but the patient is anxious about undergoing any further invasive procedures. An ultrasound is performed, and the physician measures the uterocervical length to assess the uterine anatomy, which will guide further management, including the potential insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD). What is the normal uterocervical length in an adult woman?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6-7 cm


The normal uterocervical length, including the uterine cavity and cervical canal, is typically 6-7 cm. This measurement is crucial in gynecological evaluations and procedures, such as IUD insertions, to ensure proper fit and minimize complications. A uterocervical length outside this range may indicate anatomical abnormalities or variations that could impact clinical decisions.

 

Additional relevant anatomical measurements include:

 

Ovary: The ovary typically measures about 3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm. These dimensions help assess ovarian size and function during pelvic ultrasound evaluations.

 

Fallopian Tube: The fallopian tube is approximately 10 cm in length, with a lumen diameter of 1-2 mm at the isthmus. Understanding the length and structure of the fallopian tubes is essential in assessing tubal patency and function, particularly in infertility workups.

 

Educational Objective:


The normal uterocervical length in an adult woman is 6-7 cm. Recognizing standard anatomical measurements, including the ovary (3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm) and fallopian tube (10 cm length, 1-2 mm lumen), is essential in guiding gynecological assessments and procedures to ensure accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine

 

The question asks which of the listed options is not a neurotransmitter derived from amino acids. To answer this, let's break down each of the options:

 

  • Dopamine is a well-known neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is first converted to DOPA, which then converts to dopamine. Dopamine plays various roles in the brain, including involvement in reward, motivation, and the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
  • Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Tryptophan is converted into 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is then decarboxylated to form serotonin. Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, sleep, and other functions.
  • GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate. The conversion of glutamate to GABA involves a decarboxylation reaction that requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor. GABA plays a crucial role in reducing neuronal excitability throughout the nervous system.
  • Creatine, however, is not a neurotransmitter. While creatine is synthesized from the amino acids glycine, arginine, and methionine, it functions primarily as a molecule that helps to supply energy to cells, particularly muscle cells, by regenerating ATP (adenosine triphosphate). Creatine is not involved in neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine.

 

Option B. Serotonin: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tryptophan.

 

Option C. GABA: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatine is not a neurotransmitter. It is a molecule that plays a key role in energy metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, but it does not function in neurotransmission. Dopamine, serotonin, and GABA, on the other hand, are all neurotransmitters derived from amino acids.

questions.text: According to the latest labour care guidelines, the partogram is plotted in regular intervals after _ cm dilatation: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 cm

 

  • Earlier, in the WHO modified partograph, labor is graphed and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In this partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • As per the WHO modified partograph, plotting is started at 4cm cervical dilatation, and the 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • As per the Labor Care Guide, plotting is started at 5 cm cervical dilatation

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?(INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  1, 2

 

The Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles are components of the pelvic diaphragm, commonly referred to as the levator ani.

 

The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition between the true pelvis and the perineum. It is formed by the large levator ani and small coccygeus muscles of two sides and their covering fasciae.

 

 

1. Iliococcygeus: The iliococcygeus is one of the muscles that form the pelvic diaphragm. It is part of the levator ani muscle group. The levator ani consists of the iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. The iliococcygeus muscle extends from the ischial spine (a bony projection in the pelvis) to the coccyx (the tailbone) and contributes to the support of the pelvic floor.
 

2. Pubococcygeus: The pubococcygeus muscle is another component of the levator ani muscle group and is a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It extends from the pubic bone to the coccyx and helps maintain pelvic organ support and control.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Obturator Internus: The obturator internus is not considered a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It is a separate muscle located in the pelvic region, and its primary function is to laterally rotate the thigh. While it is near the pelvic diaphragm, it does not contribute to its formation.
 

4. Deep Transverse Perinei: The deep transverse perineal muscles are not typically considered part of the pelvic diaphragm. These muscles are located in the perineum (the area between the anus and the genitalia) and play a role in stabilizing the perineal body and supporting the pelvic organs. They are important for urinary and fecal continence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles (part of the levator ani muscle group). The obturator internus and deep transverse perineal muscles are nearby but are not considered part of the pelvic diaphragm itself.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

 

Points in favor:

 

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts are smaller (8-12 µm) and round, with variable acid-fast staining. They sporulate in soil and contain two sporocysts with two sporozoites each.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are even smaller (4-6 µm) and round. They are uniformly acid-fast and contain four sporozoites. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are obligate intracellular parasites that do not have the same oocyst structure as coccidian parasites. They are detected by different staining methods and appear as small spores rather than larger oocysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

choices.text: SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age < 60 years

 

The ABCD2 score is a clinical tool used to predict the short-term risk of stroke after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The scoring system includes several factors that help assess this risk. Here’s why option A is the correct answer:

 

  • Age < 60 years: According to the ABCD2 scoring system, a patient who is aged 60 years or older scores 1 point, indicating a higher risk. Therefore, being younger than 60 does not contribute to an increased score, making it the correct choice for the exception in this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duration of TIA > 5 mins: In the ABCD2 score, the duration of the TIA is an important factor. TIA lasting 10-59 minutes scores 1 point, and TIA lasting more than 60 minutes scores 2 points. Duration less than 10 minutes would score 0. However, since the option simply says "Duration of TIA > 5 mins," without specifying how much longer, it's less clearly defined in this question, but generally longer durations imply a higher score.

 

Option C. SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg: High blood pressure at the time of TIA, defined as SBP ≥ 140 mm Hg or DBP ≥ 90 mm Hg, scores 1 point in the ABCD2 score.

 

Option D. Diabetes: The presence of diabetes in a patient who has experienced a TIA adds 1 point to the ABCD2 score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional D3-Dual TIA (within 7 days of first TIA), Imaging (MRI, DWI) were added to original score. However, all these perform very poorly in the light of recent evidences.

questions.text: What is the test of significance conducted for two or more proportions? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used to determine if there is a significant association between categorical variables. It is especially useful for testing the relationship between two or more proportions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Student's test: This typically refers to the t-test, which is used to compare means between two groups. It is not appropriate for proportions.

 

Option C. Z test: While the Z test can be used for proportions, it is usually employed for large sample sizes and comparing the means of two populations.

 

Option D. ANOVA: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups, not for comparing proportions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following has familial inheritance? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Retinitis pigmentosa
  3. Муоріа
  4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All the above conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) have a familial inheritance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: A 18-months-old child is brought to the pediatric outpatient department by his parents with concerns about his growth. The parents report that the child can run and climb stairs but occasionally falls. On examination, the child’s height appears to be around 85 cm. The pediatrician decides to assess the child’s growth in comparison to standard growth charts. The parents are also curious to know at what age their child will attain half of his adult height. What is the typical age range when a child attains half of their adult height?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18-24 months


Children typically attain half of their adult height by the age of 18-24 months. During this period, a child’s growth rate slows compared to the first year of life but remains significant. Monitoring height and weight using standard growth charts during regular health visits, such as vaccination appointments, helps in assessing normal growth patterns and identifying any abnormalities early. Measuring the length in children under two years using an infantometer or rigid measuring table provides the most accurate assessment. The correct positioning of the child during measurement ensures reliable data.

 

Educational Objective:


Children typically reach half of their adult height between 18-24 months. Accurate height measurement during this period is crucial for tracking growth and identifying deviations early, allowing for timely intervention when necessary.

questions.text: A clinician is examining various approaches to determine the rate at which a contraceptive method fails. Which index is specifically employed for this purpose? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Pearl index

 

  • Pearl index is the common method used to measure contraceptive failure rate.
  • It is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). This rate is given by the formula:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharmacological index: This term is generally refers to the study and categorization of drugs based on their effects and properties.

 

Option C. Performance index: This may refer to various metrics used to evaluate the performance of processes or systems in different fields.

 

Option D. Efficacy index: While this might be used to measure the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

 

Systemic sclerosis, also known as scleroderma, is characterized by fibrosis and tightening of the skin, particularly on the face and extremities. The presence of numbness in the fingertips is often due to Raynaud's phenomenon, which is common in systemic sclerosis and results from vasospasm and ischemia.

 

The positive ANA test with a nucleolar pattern is highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis. This pattern is seen in more than 95% of patients with scleroderma. Specific antibodies associated with systemic sclerosis include anti-centromere antibodies (often found in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis) and anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies (associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sjogren's syndrome: Sjogren's syndrome primarily affects exocrine glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth. It can also present with positive ANA, but the nucleolar pattern is not typically associated with Sjogren's. The physical findings of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not characteristic of Sjogren's syndrome.

 

Option C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide range of symptoms and often includes positive ANA. However, the nucleolar pattern is less common in SLE. The characteristic features of SLE include malar rash, arthritis, and serositis, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints, causing chronic inflammatory polyarthritis. While ANA can be positive in rheumatoid arthritis, the nucleolar pattern and symptoms of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: Identify the factor 'L' which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in given coagulation cascade? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor VII

 

The factor marked as 'L' is factor VII, which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX.

 

 

Thrombin also activates factor XIlI, which is the fibrin stabilizing factor to factor XIlla. This factor XIlla forms covalent cross-links and thereby stabilizes the fibrin clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII: Involved in the initiation of the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Works as a cofactor for Factor IXa in the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option D. VWF (Von Willebrand Factor): Involved in platelet adhesion and stabilization of Factor VIII but is not involved in the activation of the coagulation cascade by tissue factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is the key clotting factor that combines with tissue factor to activate Factor IX and Factor X, playing a crucial role in the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to which of the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Albumin

 

  • Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to albumin whereas basic /cationic drugs bind to α1 acid glycoprotein.
  • E.g., of drugs that bind to albumin are Aspirin, Barbiturates, Methotrexate.
  • E.g., of drugs that bind to α1 acid glycoprotein are Atropine, morphine, amphetamine etc

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globulin: Globulins are another class of plasma proteins but are not the primary binding proteins for anionic and weakly acidic drugs. They are involved more in immune functions and binding specific hormones and metal ions.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein: Lipoproteins are complexes that transport lipids in the blood. They are not typically involved in binding anionic and weakly acidic drugs.

 

Option D. Alpha-1 glycoprotein: Alpha-1 glycoprotein (or alpha-1 acid glycoprotein) binds primarily to basic or cationic drugs, not to anionic and weakly acidic drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind predominantly to albumin in the plasma. This binding affects their pharmacokinetics, distribution, and overall bioavailability.

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.text: The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

 

The best indicators for air pollution surveillance are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

 

  • Overall best Air Pollution Indicator - SO2
  • Overall best chemical Indicator of Air Pollution - SO2
  • Best biological Indicator of Air Pollution → LICHENS
  • Air Pollution Monitoring → CPCB [Central Pollution Control Board]

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. These provide a comprehensive assessment of air quality and are crucial for monitoring the impact on health and the environment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the most useful diagnostic investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT Thorax

 

CECT is preferred when suspicion of malignancy is high. HRCT is preferred to look at lung parenchyma/suspected ILD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI is used to assess for metastasis, secondary changes. MRI is NOT preferred over CT scan for evaluation of distant metastasis and invasion.

 

Option B. Bronchoscopy is used for biopsy of mass based on accessibility. More central masses are amenable to bronchoscopic biopsy. Peripheral masses are sampled by CT-guided biopsy.

 

Option D. Bronchography is no longer used in today’s practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The choice of CT Thorax (HRCT or CECT) is critical for early detection of potential malignancies or other significant lung conditions in a high-risk individual, particularly when initial less sensitive tests like chest X-ray and sputum analysis have failed to elucidate the cause of symptoms.

 

Reference - (Harrison 21E, 597,598) Resp Med/Hemoptysis/Lung CA

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chylomicron

 

Chylomicron levels are increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is responsible for breaking down triglycerides in chylomicrons. In its absence, chylomicrons accumulate in the bloodstream, leading to elevated chylomicron levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) levels may be elevated as well in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, but this increase is primarily associated with genetic factors and not directly related to a fatty meal.

 

Option C. HDL: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) levels are typically not significantly affected by lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Option D. Apo A: Apolipoprotein A (Apo A) is a component of HDL and is not directly increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia

questions.text: What is the skin manifestation seen resulting from drugs used to treat amebic dysentery? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fixed drug eruption

 

  • Among the various medication available, metronidazole is drug used to treat amebic dysentery most frequently & it is associated with fixed drug eruption (FDE), which is a drug-induced skin manifestation.
  • Metronidazole can cause maculopapular rashes, but it also has a higher likelihood of causing a fixed drug eruption.
  • Fixed drug eruptions/ reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They can cause a burning sensation and appear on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa.
  • They frequently appear alone or in small groups and return to the same spot. On re-exposure to the harmful drug, however, new lesions may develop on various body parts. FDE is a form of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Some of the most frequently prescribed medications that cause FDE are NSAIDs Tetracyclines and paracetamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urticaria

 

  • While urticaria (hives) can be a common reaction to many drugs, it is not specifically associated with the treatment of amoebic dysentery.
  • Urticaria is characterized by raised, often itchy, red or skin-colored wheals on the surface of the skin as shown below.

 

 

  • It is usually as an immediate hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Option C. Maculopapular rash

 

  • A maculopapular rash is a skin change that can occur with many conditions or as a reaction to various drugs.
  • It is characterized by a flat, red area on the skin that is covered with small confluent bumps as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • While this type of rash can be seen with many types of medications, it is not the most characteristic skin manifestation resulting from drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition characterized by itchy, inflamed skin.
  • It is not a drug-induced condition but rather a type of eczema that has a strong genetic predisposition and is commonly associated with allergic diseases.
  • It is not typically associated with amoebic dysentery treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fixed drug eruption is a skin manifestation commonly associated with the drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery (Metronidazole).
  • While other skin reactions can occur due to various drugs, fixed drug eruptions are characterized by recurrent lesions at the same site upon re-exposure to a particular drug.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 118 page no 118.11-12
